content: Assuming the banks will repay the money that the government is "loaning" them, should they have to repay the government with interest? If so, should the interest rate be the same as the interest rates that the banks give the consumers, especially the ones who pay on time and still have their rates risen?

content: Even if they fail completely the government will get some of it's money back. The government is first in line of all the bond holders.

content: quote: Originally posted by ErichG2: Even if they fail completely the government will get some of it's money back. The government is first in line of all the bond holders. Agreeing with you in concept, I still think it is problematic since a complete failure will require coverage of FDIC-insured customer accounts. I recognize that they are two different pockets ... but ultimately they are on the same pair of pants. To the second part of his question, banks are being required to pay interest ... but it is nowhere near the interest being charged by banks on loans and credit cards. One might wish, from a "fair is fair" standpoint that the rates were equal ... but that would defeat the prupose of the loans.
